snippet: Appealing the case of a Greenwich Village fortuneteller convicted of grand larceny, lawyers argue that if a judge had addressed the note, the outcome of the case may have changed.
abstract: Michael Wilson Crime Scene column examines effort to appeal 15-year prison sentenced handed in 2013 to Greenwich Village clairvoyant Sylvia Mitchell; lawyers for Mitchell, who was convicted on grand larceny charges, are focusing on short note sent to judge during jury deliberations stating that jury was hung on some charges; defense argues note, which was not read into court record and not addressed openly, was not given adequate attention.
lead_paragraph: Appealing the case of a Greenwich Village fortuneteller convicted of grand larceny, lawyers argue that if a judge had addressed the note, the outcome of the case may have changed.

headline.print_headline: Overlooked Note From the Jury Clouds a Convicted Fortuneteller’s Future
headline.main: Overlooked Jury Note Clouds a Convicted Fortuneteller’s Fate
